titlestmt.titleproper: Finding aid to the Margot Gayle papers SSC.MS.00061
titlestmt.author: Madison White, Ellice Amanna

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-05-16 15:09:03 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Finding aid is written in English

change.item: This record was migrated from InMagic DB Textworks to ArchivesSpace.

did.abstract: Margot Gayle was a writer, politician, and homemaker. She was a Democratic candidate for City Council in New York City in 1957. The Margot Gayle Papers consist of clippings about women from the New York Times, 1967-69.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Margot Gayle was a writer, politician, and homemaker. In 1957 she was a Democratic candidate for City Council in New York City.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Margot Gayle clippings, Sophia Smith Collection, SSC-MS-00061, Smith College, Northampton, Mass.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consist of clippings about women from the New York Times, 1967-69.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for use without restriction beyond the standard terms and conditions of Smith College Special Collections.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: To the extent that she owns copyright, Margot Gayle has assigned the copyright in her works to Smith College; however, copyright in other items in this collection may be held by their respective creators. For reproductions of materials that are governed by fair use as defined under U. S. Copyright Law, no permission to cite or publish is required. For instances which may regard materials in the collection not created by Gayle, researchers are responsible for determining who may hold materials' copyrights and obtaining approval from them. Researchers do not need anything further from Smith College Special Collections to move forward with their use.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: These papers were donated by Margot Gayle in 1969.
